folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
1 to 6 Washington Square North, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of University Place. Compare this with later pictures of this block.
September 8, 1905.

Brown Brothers.

(2)
1 to 5 Washington Square North, the same houses, nearly thirty years later, seen across the N.E. corner of Washington Square from Washington Square East and Washington Place. The view at the right is north on Washington Square East and University Place. New York University students and others may be seen along the sidewalk on either side of Washington Square.
February 23, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square North, from University Place to Macdougal Street, seen across the N.E. corner of the park. The Washington Arch is shown at the left.

April 1925.

Brown Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square North, west from (No. 8, right) a point to the west of University Place. On the right are fine old private residences that face onto Washington Square. At the left and in said park is the famous Washington Arch, heading as it does, Fifth Avenue. This thoroughfare appears in the center of this view. The buildings this side of same are in the Spring of 1939 to be reconstructed for apartment use. This is in variance to their past history as the Sailors Snug Harbor Corporation their owner has made a feature of their residential aspects. Across the Avenue at the N. W. corner is the former Rhinelander home which has gone thru this process, retaining its external appearance.

Ewing Galloway

Around 1925
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
1-13 Washington Square North, from University Place to Fifth Avenue, seen across the N.E. corner of the park. The view on University Place is north along the west side, up to Union Square. These old houses, except No. 3, the building with the fire escapes, are old residences ante dating the Civil War. In the right background may be seen the Metropolitan Life Insurance tower at Madison Avenue and 24th Street. Around 1926.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)

3-13 Washington Square North, north side, from but not including University Place to but not including Fifth Ave., with the new No. One Fifth Ave. apartment hotel rising in the background. The view is across the Square from the S.E. corner.

December 28, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, showing more of the S.E. side of Washington Square Park.

February 23, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

The same, two years later, as seen from the S.E. corner of Washington Square. The Empire State Building, in the far background, has been erected since the date of the previous view.

July, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: University Place & Waverly Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
University Place, north from Waverly Place (Washington Square North). University Place is a continuation of Wooster Street; the name University Place was applied to this part of it some time in the 1840's. New York University was incorporated in 1831, and shortly thereafter built its first building on Washington Square South at Waverly Place.

February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Washington Square North, west from University Place, showing various private dwellings (erected about 1830) that face Washington Square. The block front in the foreground are holdings of the Sailors Smug Harbor. Fifth Avenue is in the center and the Rhinelander stands at the far corner. View 2 is similar, from a point closer to Fifth Avenue.

P. L. Sperr
View 1: April 26, 1933
View 2: August 25, 1933

(2)
Washington Square North, looking towards Fifth Avenue from University Place. Former residential section of New York's Four Hundred.

P. L. Sperr
May 11, 1940

(3)
Washington Square North, looking towards Fifth Avenue from University Place. Former residential section of New York's Four Hundred.

P. L. Sperr
May 11, 1940

title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
7-8 Washington Square North, between University Place and Fifth Ave; No. 7 is on the right.
About 1935.

R. W. Hill.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: Washington Square & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square Park, central and southwestern quarter, seen from 1 University Place. Children may be seen bathing in the center fountain.
The old Hotel Holley, 35-6 Washington Scuare West, is sandwiched in between two new buildings erected around 1930. On the S.W. corner of 4th and Macdougal Streets may be seen the Washington View apartments, erected in the late 1880's. The Judson Memorial Baptist Church on the S.W. corner of Thompson Street is not quite all in the picture. The tower adjoining it is part of the same building; it was formerly the Judson Hotel, but is
now a New York University dormitory.
On the horizon may be seen the North River and the Palisades.
July 17, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, not showing the Holley Chambers at 33 Washington Square West, but including the entire Judson Memorial Church.
July 17, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square - University Place

title: Manhattan: Washington Square - University Place

folder: Washington Square & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square Park, the northwestern corner, seen from 71 Washington Square South. In the foreground is the fountain, used as a children's swimming pool, and Washington Arch. In the background may be seen the old Jefferson Market clock tower
at Sixth Avenue and 10th Street.
Between the new apartment building (circa 1928) at 30 Washington Square West and the Richmond Hill (circa 1900) may be seen the Earle Hotel at 103 Waverly Place, adjoining the N.W. corner, which is occupied by the Earle Annex. This is one of the
Knott hotels, built around 1905.
July, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but not showing the corners of Washington Square North
and Fifth Avenue.
July, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A similar view as seen from No. 1 University Place.

title: Manhattan: Washington Square - University Place

folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
1-13 Washington Square North, (right to left) north side, from University Place to Fifth Avenue as seen from the roof of 71 Washington Square South, across the Park, with the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue in the foreground and the midtown skyscrapers in the background. The Empire State Building (1930) rises behind 55 Fifth Avenue, to the center of the picture. To the right of same appears the Metropolitan tower (1907) and the New York Life Bldg. (1926) and the Chrysler Bldg. (1930) at 42nd Street. Partially shown in a decapitated form in the foreground, is No. 1 Fifth Avenue, a modern Apartment house.

July 1935.
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr.

No. 3.

An eastward view of the same row of buildings as photographed from Fifth Avenue. In the background, at the S.E. and N.E. corners respectively of Waverly Place, appears the law department of New York University and a new Apartment house.

May 7, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
6 Washington Square North, north side, between University Place and Fifth Avenue, showing the lower portion and entrance to one of the row of old New York residences. These are the Sailors. Snug Harbor holdings.

1939

Gift of Beecher Ogden
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place

folder: Washington Square & University Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Washington Square Park:  A northeastward view from the center towards University and Waverly Places.  At the N. E. corner of that point is the large apartment house, No. 1 University Place.  To the right is the 11-story building that houses the Law Department of N. Y. U.  This fronts on Washington Square East and extends from Washington Place on the right, to Waverly Place on the left.  The 5th Avenue buses terminate their run here and return northward.  The operator of one is shown changing his route sign.  Note the Columbus statue opened to view in No. 2.  Both of these photos are from the same point of vantage.

June 9, 1940
Views 1,2

F. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: Washington Square - University Place
